With Father Fulgentio, who, according to Archbishop Tenison¹⁷, was ‘a Divine (if 1 mis- take not) of the Republic of Venice, and the same who wrote the Life of his Colleague, the excellent Father Paul,' passed at least one interchange of letters. Here, again, the letter of Fulgentio is unfortunately lost, but Bacon’s reply is given in Tenison’s Baconiana (pp. 196-200), and in the seventh volume 01 Spedding's Life and Letters of Bacon, pp. 531-533.

Attention'is drawn by Mr. Napier to a cutibus and interesting letter from Toby Matthevr to Bacon, dated Brussels, April 4, 1619¹⁸, in which he connects the name of Bacon with that ol Galileo. ‘It may please your Lordship, there was with me this day one Mr. Richard white, who hath spent some little time at Florence, and is now gone into England. He tells me, that Galileo had ansvered your discourse concerning the flux and reflux of the sea, and was sending it unto me; but that Mr. White hindered him, because his answer was grounded upon a false supposition, namely, that there · was in the ocean a full sea but once in twenty-four hours. But now lwill call upon Galileo again! As the tract De Fluxu et Refluru Maris was not published till it was included in Gruter's collection of 1653, it must have been communicated to Galileo in manuscript, thus shewing the interest already taken in Bacon’s writings. Itis true, 1 believe, that Galileo makes no mention of Bacon's works, but then, as 1 shall presently have occasion to remark, ¹and as we have already seen in the case of Loelre‚ the habit oi referring to . contemporary or recent writers was at this time comparatively rare.
